awd_titl_txt: "Research Initiation Award" - The Genetic Code of Protein Molecules
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

inst.inst_name: University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The research project on genetic code commenced three and a half years ago. The research goal is to update scientific knowledge on the emergence of a standard alphabet of 20 genetically encoded amino acids. There are two specific objectives. The first objective is to explore the current assertion that the standard amino acid alphabet comprises a mixture of “early” versus “late” members; that is, some amino acids were available prebiotically and were therefore present from the start of genetic coding; others evolved later, as “inventions” of early metabolism; and analyze the metabolic pathways at work in living organisms so as to provide evidence based information into ancient molecular evolution, such as the steps by which life’s biochemical framework first emerged. The second objective is to train and mentor four students in evolutionary research. We completed  the following in those years:

  • Identification of the enzymes associated with each step of amino acid biosynthesis,
  • Identification of which of these enzymes occur within all three domains of life. 
  • Verify which enzymes are missing from one or more domains of life,
  • Reduce/simplify sequence data sets for each step of a metabolic pathway,
  • Identify pathways and build phylogenies for the amino acids and enzymes respectively, of each step in the amino acid’s biosynthetic pathway,
  • Identify and eliminate examples of lateral gene transfer.
  • Data analysis and evolutionary interpretation
  • Building the phylogenetic tree

 We presented results as follows:

  • Showed the phylogeny of enzymes involved in the biosynthesis of the 20 standard amino acids of the genetic code as distributed in the three domains of life.
  • Showed taxonomic and/or evolutionary relationships of the enzymes.
  • Produced detailed and updated pathways of biosynthesis of 20 standard amino acids of the genetic code using available data from 1975 – 2017.

We traveled to the National Autonomous University of Mexico (UNAM) in summer, 2016 to conduct research at the Origin of Life laboratory, courtesy of Dr. Lazcano and Dr. Arturo (world-renowned evolutionary scientists).  The PI and two students (Annette and Makoneen) spent over three weeks at UNAM. 

We identified and documented all new biosynthetic pathways of the 20 standard amino acids (1975 – 2017). These pathways were not available during the Co-Evolutionary theory in 1975, and many of the pathways were not represented in the publication of Hernandez and co-workers in 2008. Using new data, we have completed sequence alignment and BLAST analyses of enzymes involved in the pathways. Based on available new research data, we produced new and/or updated pathways (please see Fig. 2 attached) of biosynthesis of each of the 20 standard amino acids of the genetic code. We also produced the phylogeny of enzymes involved in the biosynthesis of the 20 standard amino acids (Figs. 1a and 1b).

 KEY OUTCOMES:

  • Distinctions exist between the “early” and “late” amino acids of the genetic code.
  • Biosynthetic steps in many of the late amino acids are longer than those in the early ones.
  • Longer step means the involvement of many more enzymes.
  • Synthesis of some late amino acids is not “a one-way traffic” from early members because some late amino acids can give rise to some early amino acids through well-defined pathways, which complicates some of the key assertions of the Co-Evolutionary theory.
  • Contrary to the Co-evolutionary theory, there is no precursor-product relationship that connects some early and late amino acids such as Glycine (Gly), early amino acid and Threonine (Thr), late amino acid. Yet, our results show new pathways that facilitate the biosynthesis of Thr from Gly and/or vice-versa. Several other such examples exist in our new updated pathways with respect to early versus late amino acid biosyntheses.  
  • Some enzymes are distributed in the three domains (Eukarya, Bacteria, and Archaea); some appear in two domains, while six enzymes are restricted to one domain. The enzymes: 1.2.1.71; 2.6.1.1; 2.6.1.58; 4.2.1.49 are restricted to Bacteria. The enzyme 2.6.1.9 is restricted to Eukarya, and the enzyme 4.3.1.3 is restricted to Archaea. Since each of the three domains has at least one unique enzyme, we propose that these six enzymes are ancient or vestiges of the Last Universal Common Ancestor (LUCA), which gave rise to other enzymes involved in the evolutionary pathways. Indeed, this occurrence suggests that molecular evolution is a continuous phenomenon. The fact that vestiges of enzymes from LUCA are still traceable in present day living organisms suggests that metabolic pathways found in living organisms can indeed give accurate guide to ancient evolutionary events. Hence, these pathways can rightly be referred to as “molecular fossils”.

Project outcomes resulted in several juried publications.

The following students conducted research in the project:

  1. Ms Kerian Trice (BS Biology 2014, BSN 2016)
  2. Mr. Daniel Machooka (BS Chemistry 2013, MS Computer Science – Bioinformatics 2015; US-Army)
  3. Mr Makonnen Moorhead (BS Computer Science - 2016)
  4. Ms Annette Craig-Hall (BS Computer Science – Bioinformatics 2018)

Last Modified: 01/04/2018
Modified by: Joseph Onyilagha
